points.title: Define user needs
points.keyquestion: How has the project or programme defined user needs?
points.summary: Understand your users and their needs. Develop knowledge of your users and what that means for your technology project or programme.
prompts: Have you carried out user research in the form of multiple interviews or observations of the users?
Do you have a thorough knowledge of who your users are?
Does your evidence support your understanding of your users’ needs?
Can you describe how your service/product reflects the needs of the user?
antipatterns: Too few users have been contacted, and the project or programme has mainly used its own knowledge to develop a list of user needs.
Only using group sessions to present ideas and request feedback. The project or programme will receive useful information but it will be too general to create detailed personas.
Describing users’ needs in a way that is too technical or system-focused and does not reflect what a user would say or think.
Assuming that the users’ needs or the created personas have not changed significantly from the business case stage.

expected.description: The project or programme conducts individual user interviews, as well as presentations or consultations with groups.
The project or programme has identified users with different needs. They are grouped by goals or activities rather than demographics. User personas might be used to illustrate these different groups.

strong.short-description: The team has a prioritised backlog
strong.description: The project or programme works from a prioritised backlog of user needs, written in the form of user stories.

strong.short-description: The team uses a variety of research methods
strong.description: The project or programme has used a variety of user research methods, including ethnographic, one-to-one interviews and usability testing.

exceptional.short-description: The team changes their requirements based on research
exceptional.description: The project or programme has changed its system requirements or scope due to insights from user research.

exceptional.short-description: The team shares their discovered user needs widely
exceptional.description: The project or programme has contributed discovered user needs to help other programmes or departments.

points.title: Make things accessible
points.keyquestion: How has the project or programme made the technology project or programme accessible?
points.summary: Make sure your technology, infrastructure and systems are accessible for users.
prompts: Have you involved users with a range of accessibility needs in user testing?
What range of devices do you need to work with your technology?
Can users access your services in different web browsers?
Is your service/system compatible with assistive technologies?
antipatterns: The service does not render or behave properly when JavaScript is turned off.
Accessibility has been evaluated based on the project or programme’s investigation, but not actually tested with users.
The project or programme cites an expected standard, such as WCAG2 AA or AAA, without showing actual testing and mitigation of issues.
Assuming that administrative or internal user interfaces are exempt from accessibility requirements.

expected.description: The project or programme has created user interfaces that work well using standard HTML and CSS elements. They are making progress on adding advanced CSS or scripting functionality.
The project or programme is using internal or external accessibility experts to evaluate the project or programme for any accessibility issues.

strong.description: The project or programme has acted to mitigate all high-impact and most medium-impact accessibility recommendations.
The project or programme contains at least one expert on accessibility issues, and all members have completed accessibility training.

exceptional.description: The project or programme regularly test the technology with a panel of users with accessibility needs.
The project or programme creates and talks about accessibility standards both in and outside the organisation. They participate in cross-government accessibility forums.

points.title: Be open and use open source
points.keyquestion: What actions has the project or programme taken to publish any code or use open source?
points.summary: Publish your code and use open source to improve transparency, flexibility and accountability.
prompts: How much is it going to cost to create and run the solution?
Will the staff need training or will you need to employ experts to manage the solution?
If you are using open source, how widely is the code already adopted? How mature is it?
Does the solution offer the level of support needed?
If you’re buying a solution, can you assess it’s reliability based on its maturity?
If you’re buying a solution, can you assess its performance based on data or reviews?
Is the solution flexible?
Will the solution work with your other technology?
Is the solution’s licence acceptable to your organisation’s business requirements?
Is the solution’s warranty acceptable and is there an option to buy one?
antipatterns: Project or programme members are unclear how they can use open source in their project or programme. They avoid using open source instead of examining how it can meet user needs and deliver the solution.
The project or programme has published its code but has not added history tracking or clear supporting documentation.
The project or programme has assumed that security reasons are preventing them from publishing some or all of their code without checking the security guidance and exceptions.

expected.description: The project or programme does fair evaluations of open source options to see if there are any that meet the needs of the project or programme.
The project or programme makes new code created by the programme available in an open repository.

strong.description: The project or programme maintains open code repositories by using commit histories, pull requests and clear documentation.
The project or programme members have the skills and confidence to improve or adapt an open-source solution or platform.

exceptional.description: The project or programme contributes to shared platforms to help improve either their own systems so they are easier to use by others, or cross-government services.
The project or programme publishes a complete set of documentation that is managed as code and kept in synch with the service code.

points.title: Make use of open standards
points.keyquestion: How does the project or programme make use of open standards?
points.summary: Build technology that uses open standards to ensure your technology works and communicates with other technology, and can easily be upgraded and expanded.
prompts: Have you made use of open standards, complying with any that are compulsory for use in government?
Are you clear about what data your systems hold?
How do you avoid duplication of data?
Are you clear whether you are using the approved source of data rather than a copy or different version?
How have you used RESTful APIs for integration where possible?
Have you considered if your technology has the flexibility for you to move it to other systems or services?
antipatterns: The project or programme has not investigated whether they can use standards for data, APIs, or common identifiers.
The project or programme is using machine-to-machine communications that they cannot encode using human-readable formats.

expected.description: The project or programme is using applicable open standards that are mandatory for government use.

expected.short-description: Selects appropriate open standards to meet user needs
expected.description: The project or programme selects the open standards that meet their users’ needs and either implement them or lists them in the requirements to their supplier.

strong.short-description: Makes data as open as possible
strong.description: The project or programme uses open standards to make their data as open as possible.

strong.short-description: Uses open standards to be compatible with future technology changes
strong.description: The project or programme uses open standards that are compatible with any future technology upgrades.

exceptional.description: The project or programme promotes the use of open standards.

exceptional.short-description: Contributes to development of open standards
exceptional.description: The project or programme contributes to the development of open standards.

points.title: Use cloud first
points.keyquestion: How is the project or programme using cloud-based technology?
points.summary: Use public cloud first as stated in the government’s cloud first policy.
prompts: How do you evaluate potential public cloud services before considering alternatives such as data centres?
Can you demonstrate that your chosen service represents the best value for money?
Have you been in contact with the GOV.UK PaaS team about the hosting requirements for the service?
antipatterns: The project or programme is using a 'private cloud' without regulatory or security justification.
Although the project or programme is using a public cloud (for example, AWS, Azure or Google Cloud), they use the generic service without taking advantage of specific cloud components.
The organisation has multiple accounts with the same cloud provider and does not share components such as identity management, log-in or security infrastructure.
The organisation still has on-premise servers and does not have a plan to use either Crown Hosting or a virtualised cloud environment.
The project or programme does not consider using GOV.UK PaaS for hosting or dismisses using it with no justification.

expected.description: The project or programme can demonstrate that the alternative to the cloud they have selected offers better value for money.
The project or programme can show they have considered possible SaaS (software as a service) solutions before proposing bespoke developments.

strong.description: The project or programme can demonstrate that they have evaluated GOV.UK PaaS as a potential provider in addition to other cloud providers.

exceptional.description: The project or programme has made us of advances in cloud technology (for example, containerisation) to improve their solution.

points.title: Make things secure
points.keyquestion: What actions has the project or programme taken to add the appropriate security?
points.summary: Keep systems and data safe with the appropriate level of security.
prompts: Have you considered the security risks around your technology and how to mitigate them?
Should a security risk occur do you have processes in place to improve the time taken to recover?
Have you followed the principles set out in the Security policy framework and Security classification policy?
Have you followed the National Cyber Security Centre’s information risk management guidance?
How have you designed and implemented the components of your system according to government best practice?
How have you determined the security requirements of cloud services using the Cloud security principles and accompanying guidance?

expected.description: The project or programme can demonstrate how they are implementing the appropriate level of security.
The project or programme provide well-documented security processes and make sure that all relevant staff members use them.

strong.description: The project or programme has processes in place to improve the mean time to recovery in addition to the regular processes.
The project or programme can provide evidence of how they are following security guidance from the NCSC.

exceptional.short-description: Taken into account interactions with other systems
exceptional.description: The project or programme has taken into account interactions with other services and systems and where necessary made suggestions for improvements to the security interactions.
The project or programme is using or has created, reusable security components.

points.title: Make privacy integral
points.keyquestion: How has the project or programme made privacy integral?
points.summary: Make sure citizens’ rights are protected by integrating privacy as an essential part of your system.
prompts: Will the project or programme collect new information about individuals?
Will individuals have to provide information about themselves to the project or programme?
Will information about individuals be disclosed to parties that have not previously had routine access?
Are you using information about individuals in a way it is not currently used?
Have you conducted a Privacy Impact Assessment? What was the outcome?
Does the project or programme involve you using new technology that might be perceived as being privacy intrusive? For example, the use of biometrics or facial recognition?
Is the information about individuals of a kind particularly likely to raise privacy concerns or expectations? For example, health records, that people would consider to be private?
Will the project or programme require you to contact individuals in ways that they may find intrusive?

expected.short-description: Complies with the General Data Protection Regulation
expected.description: The project or programme must comply with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

expected.short-description: Clear on how to collect, use and store personal data
expected.description: The project or programme must clear about how they will collect, use and store any personal data.

strong.short-description: Uses a variety of methods to evaluate compliance with General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
strong.description: The project or programme uses a variety of methods to evaluate their performance in complying with GDPR, such as user stories, information risk assessments and data protection impact assessments.

strong.short-description: Evaluates new tools to comply with GDPR
strong.description: The project or programme evaluates new technology tools to make sure they also comply with GDPR.

exceptional.short-description: Teaches others about compliance with GDPR
exceptional.description: The project or programme use their experiences to teach other parts of the organisation about how to comply with GDPR.

points.title: Share and reuse technology
points.keyquestion: How has the project or programme made their technology shareable and reusable?
points.summary: Promote good practice and avoid duplicated efforts by sharing and reusing services, data and software components.
prompts: Have you joined one of the four cross-government technology communities that discuss the latest thinking on services?
Have you considered using common government platforms and services where appropriate?
How have you explored whether there are other government services or software components elsewhere in Government which you could use?
Have you shared or reused documentation from other discoveries, if so, what?
What existing services both in and out of government have you considered using?
How have you made your solution open for reuse?

expected.description: The project or programme can show that they have considered if there are any elements they can reuse or share so that others can reuse.
The project or programme can show they have considered using government platforms and common technology.

strong.short-description: Using government platforms and common technology
strong.description: The project or programme is using government platforms and common technology.

strong.short-description: Is open to allow for potential technology sharing
strong.description: The project or programme is as open as possible to allow for potential technology sharing.

exceptional.description: The project or programme promotes the reusable elements to encourage other teams to share and reuse technology.
The project or programme has investigated commercial aggregation opportunities with the Crown Commercial Service.

points.title: Integrate and adapt technology
points.keyquestion: How has the project or programme integrated and adapted their technology?
points.summary: Your technology should work with existing technologies, processes and infrastructure in your organisation, and adapt to future demands.
prompts: What type of integration model do you use to support your technology?
How do you identify single points of failure?
Do you use independently developed components that work together but can be easily exchanged?
How thorough is the map of your technology infrastructure?
Do you have a plan for integrating or modernising legacy systems?
Is it possible for your technology to work with legacy or newer systems?

expected.short-description: Has integration plans based on the IT operating model
expected.description: The project or programme has integration plans based on the organisation’s IT operating model, including business processes, governance, service support and service delivery.
The project or programme has a flexible approach to integration so that the system or service can incorporate legacy and new infrastructure, including the use of cloud services.

strong.short-description: Has a skills and capabilities training plan
strong.description: The project or programme has a skills and capabilities training plan.

strong.short-description: Runs regular integration and stress testing
strong.description: The project or programme regular integration and stress testing to make sure the system remains robust.

exceptional.description: The project or programme is using a continuous improvement model.

exceptional.short-description: Tracks interdependencies between infrastructure and services
exceptional.description: The project or programme tracks the interdependencies between the infrastructure and the services running on it.

points.title: Make better use of data
points.keyquestion: How is your project or programme using data?
points.summary: Consider how to minimise data collection and reuse data to avoid duplication of datasets.
prompts: How have you minimised data collection?
How have you communicated to stakeholders how data will be used?
How have you avoided duplication of datasets?
Have you anonymised personal data?
Have you considered ethical issues around using data, and assessing these according to the principles of the Data Science Ethical Framework?
How have you made newly collected data easily accessible?
What common standards and patterns have you used to ensure data can be easily analysed?
How does your solution align with best practices for collecting, storing, analysing and sharing data?

expected.short-description: Follows current guidance and best practices for data
expected.description: The project or programme follows the current guidance and best practices for managing data.

expected.short-description: Data is open by default and follows open data principles
expected.description: The project or programme makes their data open by default and follows the open data principles when publishing data.

strong.short-description: Uses common standards and platforms for data
strong.description: The project or programme uses common standards and platforms to make their data easier to analyse in a consistent way.

strong.short-description: Collection and storage of data is accessible by API
strong.description: The project or programme has a plan for the collection and storage of new data that makes it accessible for use by APIs.

exceptional.short-description: Has a strategy to retain data only as long as necessary
exceptional.description: The project or programme has a strategy for assessing the data they have and only keeping it for as long as necessary, and securely deleting the data when it’s no longer needed.

points.title: Define your purchasing strategy
points.keyquestion: How is your project or programme defining the purchasing strategy?
points.summary: Your purchasing strategy must show you’ve considered commercial and technology aspects, and contractual limitations.
prompts: Are commercial products and opportunities competitive and innovative?
Do you know your forecasted long-term financial savings?
Do you have good supplier relations?
What is your commercial approach and how does it support the disaggregation of contracts?
How does your strategy help with the transition to the cloud, commodity and common technology services?
How does your strategy support shorter, more manageable contracts with a streamlined renewal process?
Do you have a clear view of contract status, risks and issues?

expected.description: The project or programme works closely with a commercial team to identify the best products and components to purchase.
The project or programme uses off the shelf products and services where possible to avoid making customised products.

strong.description: The project or programme has a sourcing strategy that includes a plan for managing multiple suppliers.
The project or programme has a plan that shows where and how they have disaggregated the technology they are using, and the contracts that supply the technology.

exceptional.description: The project or programme regularly considers whether the requirements in their sourcing strategy can be simplified or broken up to allow for greater competition in the marketplace, including by small and medium-sized enterprises.
The project or programme uses technology components that complying with the Greening Government Commitments to reduce their environmental impact.

points.title: Meet the Digital Service Standard for digital services
points.summary: If you are building a service as part of your technology project or programme you will also need to meet the Digital Service Standard.
